awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Role of Credentialing in Promoting and Sustaining Innovative Engineering Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
The way engineers are educated must constantly evolve as the world context and the technologies evolve. While there are many successful efforts by individuals and small groups, large-scale curricular changes are key to maintaining these successes. Earlier data collected and analyzed by this team shows that one of the barriers to large-scale curricular change is understanding how to credential innovative educational practices, particularly those practices that do not take place in a traditional, lecture-oriented classroom. Credentialing is an important mark for students looking for quality education programs as well as employers looking for quality graduates. This study uses the real experiences of engineering degree programs that are innovative across their curriculum to learn how they navigated the credentialing processes. The impact of the work is to determine pathways to turn the use of credentialing as a barrier to better engineering education into a lever for getting more engineering programs to make large-scale innovations. 

Even when engineering curricular changes are systemic, earlier data collected by this team shows that credentialing is a key, though often misunderstood or not explicitly acknowledged, barrier to real, sustainable improvement to engineering education practice. Communication across implementation levels (e.g., course, curriculum, university credentialing) and their research to practice cycles is not straightforward, even though it is necessary to produce sustainable change in engineering education. Therefore, the goal of this research is to answer: What gaps exist and how do we bridge innovative curricular/pedagogical initiatives and credentialing at the institutional, federal, and accreditation levels? Data collection and analysis in years 1 and 2 will allow the team to explore and describe the role credentialing plays in sustainable engineering education change. The research team and advisory board will address ways to expand the research-to-practice cycle so that university-level infrastructure is included. The team will broadly disseminate the results via Implementation Workshops that will include faculty, administrators and staff, as well as through traditional publications and conferences. 

This work will: 1) Explore the role credentialing plays in sustainable engineering curricular change from multiple viewpoints, including faculty, academic administrators, registrar and financial aid staff, accreditors, and others; 2) Expand the research to practice cycle to include the infrastructure within which both the research and the practice occur; and 3) Develop and disseminate materials to inform change agents so they can increase the efficacy of their credentialing efforts. The results of the project include: a model of change that recognizes the potential infrastructure barriers to innovation in engineering education, materials for university change agents to help them navigate the credentialing process, and increased understanding of how to support and sustain long term change in engineering education.

por.por_cntn:
While many efforts have been made to develop these technical and professional skills in engineering graduates, there has been little change in the pedagogy of most engineering education institutions in the U.S. (National Research Council, 2012), despite the evolution of engineering education in many countries around the world.  Many of these efforts involve changing only one or two aspects of the curriculum, and are bound to fail in making significant changes in the student learning experience due to the limited change in the curriculum.  Even when engineering curricular changes are systemic, our data shows that credentialing is a key, though often misunderstood, barrier to real, sustainable improvement to engineering education practice. The major goals of this project are to:

 1. Explore the role credentialing plays in sustainable engineering curricular change from multiple viewpoints, including faculty, academic administrators, registrar and financial aid staff, accreditors, and others;

 2. Expand the research to practice cycle to include the infrastructure within which both the research and the practice occur; and

 3. Develop and disseminate materials to inform change agents so they can increase the efficacy of their credentialing efforts.

The acheive these goals, we started by collecting data from people involved in particuarly innovative engineering education departments across the nation, some of which continue as successful programs and some of which have closed for reasons beyond their control. This resulted in an initial set of published recommendations.

As we continued to analyze our interview data, we saw the additional theme emerging of the power of stories in making and sustaining improvements in engineering education. While there are more variations of the story of change in engineering education in practice than we anticipated, we are finding common threads among them; we view these as archetype stories. Within our data, we have built a language and narrative of the stories we often hear in engineering education. This process laid the groundwork for exploring interventions to change the stories and, as a consequence, change the meaning individuals make of their organizations for the better.  

An outgrowth of our study of credentialing and the dissemination through the Change Champions Roadshow is that these tools and resources have gained traction in engineering education for making systemic improvements in both credentialing and other areas of needed change. Our workshop, when offered at a partner site, consists of three on-site segments: the Building Your Team of Change Champions workshop we have offered at both the 2017 American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) conference and the 2018 Frontiers in Education conference; work time we facilitate with the team(s) invested in making and sustaining significant improvements in engineering education; and consultation time for groups and individuals we are interested in making positive change in engineering education, regardless of the size and scope of the change. Wherever possible, we make the initial half-day workshop available to other local institutions as well. We continue to recruit additional sites for taking the Change Champions Roadshow across the country, expanding the impacts of the award beyond the funding period. In order to assure that positive impact of the workshop outlast the grant period, we are creating stand-alone resources that will be disseminated widely.
